title: How to tell the end of an Ethernet cable - Quora

response.answer_text: I think I understand your issue, because it stumped me for a while. If you have Ethernet wiring in your house, all the cables to go a low voltage box or rack. You see dozens of cables. Which is the one you want? Usually, the installer will put numbers on the cables and indicate on a sheet of paper which numbered cable is in which room. Fortunately, I still had the paper. But it was rather vague. Some cables were connected to the land line telephones. The landline ring signal is over 80 volts. If I made a mistake, it could be quite expensive. The answer is an inexpensive Ethernet tester (about $15). Plug a working phone into a wall jack and make sure you don’t get a dial tone. That tells you the jack is not tied into the landline telephone. Plug in a patch cable in the wall jack. Connect it to one side of the tester. Go down to the basement, plug a likely cable into the other side of the tester, and turn on the tester. If no lights flash, you are on the wrong cable. Try again. Here’s a picture.

If you azre trying to trace a cable, without eve having to plug it in, you need a tone generator. This is a very good (but quite expensive) one: Fluke IntelliTone Pro 200 You simply plug one end in and then wave the wand near a bunch of cables. IOt will emit a tome when you are over the connected one.
